statement.text: Type A aortic dissection requires emergency surgical repair. Without surgery, mortality is 1-2% per hour in the first 48 hours, approaching 50% at 48 hours and 90% at one month. Surgical repair involves median sternotomy, cardiopulmonary bypass with deep hypothermic circulatory arrest, replacement of the ascending aorta, and management of associated pathology (aortic valve, root, arch).
statement.formal: Type A Management: Emergency OR within hours | Procedure: Median sternotomy → CPB + DHCA → Ascending aortic replacement ± root/arch | Goal: Exclude entry tear, prevent tamponade/rupture | Mortality: 15-25% surgical vs 50%+ non-operative

explanation.intuition: Type A dissection is one of the true surgical emergencies in medicine. The ascending aorta is like a time bomb - the false lumen can rupture into the pericardium (causing tamponade), tear into the coronary arteries (causing heart attack), or extend into the arch vessels (causing stroke). The only way to defuse this bomb is to cut out the diseased ascending aorta and replace it with a synthetic graft. Even with 15-25% surgical mortality, it's far better than the alternative.
explanation.key_insight: The phrase 'time is muscle' applies to MI - for Type A dissection, 'time is survival.' Every hour of delay increases mortality by 1-2%. Don't wait for extensive workup or consultation - once CT confirms Type A, go to OR. The surgical goal is simple: exclude the entry tear and prevent the most lethal complications.
explanation.technical_details: Operative approach: (1) Median sternotomy; (2) Femoral or axillary artery cannulation (avoid dissected aorta); (3) Cardiopulmonary bypass with cooling to 18-22°C; (4) Deep hypothermic circulatory arrest with cerebral protection (antegrade or retrograde); (5) Open distal anastomosis under arrest; (6) Proximal anastomosis to sinotubular junction or aortic root (if valve/root involved); (7) Rewarm and wean from bypass. Root management depends on valve/root involvement: valve resuspension, valve-sparing root replacement, or Bentall procedure (composite valve-conduit). Arch extent determines whether hemiarch or total arch replacement needed.
common_misconceptions: Wait for cardiology/vascular consult - every hour delay = increased mortality
Stabilize the patient first - OR is the stabilization
Young patients tolerate delay better - they need faster intervention to maximize life-years saved
Excellent surgical results are achievable everywhere - volume and experience matter enormously

definitions_glossary.cardiopulmonary_bypass: Machine that takes over heart and lung function during surgery
definitions_glossary.deep_hypothermic_circulatory_arrest: Cooling body to allow brief complete cessation of circulation for arch work
definitions_glossary.bentall_procedure: Composite replacement of aortic valve, root, and ascending aorta
definitions_glossary.antegrade_cerebral_perfusion: Selective brain perfusion during circulatory arrest
definitions_glossary.hemiarch_replacement: Replacement of underside of arch without full arch replacement

surgical_goals: Prevent stroke from arch vessel involvement

ascending_only.indication: Entry tear in ascending, competent valve, no arch involvement

root_involvement.indication: Root dilation, valve regurgitation, coronary involvement

arch_involvement.indication: Tear in arch, arch vessel dissection
options: Total arch with frozen elephant trunk

clinical_pearls: Don't delay surgery waiting for optimization - OR is the resuscitation
Hourly mortality 1-2% in first 48 hours - time = survival
Axillary artery preferred cannulation site - avoids dissected aorta
Volume and experience matter enormously for outcomes
